posts.name:
Linda Leüåª
Linda Leüåª
posts.content:
True happiness at work comes from feeling valued, not just employed.

You should appreciate and celebrate your employees when you have them, not when you are about to lose them.

I‚Äôve lost out on a lot of candidates due to counteroffers.

The counter offers always come from their current employer when they are seeking a new job.

The things they previously requested from their current employer all of a sudden magically appears:

 Promotion
Pay Raise
More PTO
Flexible/Remote Work
Bonuses

And they always choose to stay.

However, I‚Äôve also seen people choose a counteroffer and then they are still unhappy, because their employer only valued them when they were about to lose them to another company.

If you are not feeling valued or appreciated at your current company, it‚Äôs ok to move on instead of feeling stuck. You can revamp your resume withto help you standout, no matter what position you‚Äôre aiming for. This innovative approach not only saves you time but also ensures that your resume showcases your skills and experiences in the best possible light to find new opportunities.

Remember that the salary increases, promotions, and change in titles will never change how much your employer values you and it will always take you leaving for them to realize it.

Find a company who sees your worth while they have you, not when they are about to lose you.

comments.commentText:
You deserve a job that appreciates and celebrates all of you. 

Find a new one using Kickresume here : https://www.kickresume.com/en/ats-resume-checker/

Great insight into how counteroffers can create temporary solutions but fail to address the root cause of dissatisfaction. True value comes from being appreciated consistently, not only when you‚Äôre about to leave. Employees deserve to feel valued and respected every day, not just when they‚Äôre on the brink of moving on. If you‚Äôre not being valued, it‚Äôs okay to seek new opportunities where your worth is recognized from the start.‚Äù

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! True value comes from ongoing recognition, not just crisis management. Employees deserve to feel appreciated every day!

posts.name:
Zachary Wright MBA
Zachary Wright MBA
posts.content:
Employee engagement is an absolute disaster right now.

It's sitting at a 10 year low and has never gotten above 36%...

(Source: Gallup)

That's ugly...but here's how to solve the problem:

According to, here are 3 great ways to drive engagement:

- Hyper-personalization of work, related journeys, and training.
- Freeing up time for managers so they can actually...you know...manage. Or coach. And mentor. And give feedback. Not be stuck in email hell.
- Allow the work we do to be more human and flexible.

All are spot on but #2 is where companies go VERY wrong...

We somehow expect managers to know how to lead because we promote them. All while ignoring that leadership training and development is either non-existent or bare minimum at best. There's just no leadership from leadership!

So, if we're going to make something mandatory... shouldn't it leadership training, not returning to the office???

We need to ensure leaders are:

- Capable of leading teams with approaches that serve instead of dictate.
- Capable of managing performance based on actual outcomes instead of observation.
- Capable of establishing trust with employees to actually manage people that drives engagement.
- And making sure the people that are leaders, aren't solely in it for power and authority.

Because the numbers don't lie:

+ 70% of the variance in employee engagement is directly tied to the manager (Gallup).
+ 58% of managers report they never received any leadership training (CareerBuilder).
+ Companies that invest in leadership development see a 25% increase in organizational outcomes (Center for Creative Leadership).

Leaders are the central nervous system of the organization.

They are how employees understand what is excepted (for better or worse).

Leaders ARE engagement.

So let's equip them to be better, not worse!

Who's with me?

comments.commentText: What drives engagement? It's not news... As Daniel Pink says it's autonomy, mastery, and purpose. Foster those three things and you'll get the improvements you're looking for.

Michael Fitch the elements are out there, now the big question is, why aren‚Äôt companies adopting best practices? If we can solve that, we will see tremendous outcomes for both employees and employers!
Zachary Wright MBA I saw that, too. Little p "purpose" and Big P "purpose"... regardless, tie the work to a purpose if you want engagement.

Hits the nail on the head.....leaders are the key to engagement. The numbers don‚Äôt lie. Yet, we continuously overlook the glaring issue. Most managers are promoted without the tools to lead. Leadership isn‚Äôt instinctive.....it‚Äôs learned and earned.

We need servant leadership model that:
- Empowers, not dictates.
- Builds trust, not surveillance.
- Measures outcomes, not attendance.

Investing in leadership isn‚Äôt just a 'nice to have'. As we can see, it‚Äôs directly tied to performance, engagement and retention. If we really want employees to thrive, let‚Äôs ensure managers are equipped to lead with empathy, purpose and skill.

Sam Sahni 1000% agree! I think when we take the time to focus on the things that matter (more than RTO) then we can actually create real change that produces outcomes both good for the employee and employer. All benefit!

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Investing in leadership training is crucial for driving engagement and fostering a positive work culture. Let‚Äôs prioritize this change!

posts.content:
Still think sales is all about charisma? Think again‚Äîit‚Äôs killing your growth!

Here‚Äôs the deal: Sales isn‚Äôt magic; it‚Äôs a process. The same way you build, test, and refine your product, you need to do the same with sales.
Here‚Äôs how:
 Stop winging it. Build a system that works without micromanaging every lead.
 Track everything. Know your conversion rates, lead sources, and sales cycle‚Äîor you‚Äôre just guessing.
 Iterate constantly. Every ‚Äúno‚Äù is feedback. Use it to refine your pitch and optimize your approach.

Sales is just like product development: test, tweak, repeat. And when you treat it that way, you‚Äôre not just closing deals‚Äîyou‚Äôre building a scalable system that grows with you.

At, we help businesses automate and optimize their sales processes more effectively, so you can stop guessing and start scaling.
Ready to make sales predictable and efficient? Let‚Äôs get to work.

A clear sales strategy is the foundation for startup growth, targeted efforts lead to more meaningful connections and sustainable success.
